nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor will improve economic outcomes, cognition, productivity, decision making, and well-being

Low-income adults in Chennai are severely sleep deprived: actigraphy shows average 5.5â€“5.6 hours asleep per night despite about 8 hours in bed and low sleep efficiency (~70%) with frequent awakenings
Low sleep efficiency appears similar to clinical populations (insomnia, sleep apnea) and likely raises the opportunity cost of sleep because more time in bed is required per minute asleep

A randomized controlled trial (N=452) employed participants in a month-long data-entry job, cross-randomizing two night-sleep interventions (devices+encouragement, devices+incentives) with a workplace half-hour daily nap treatment

Actigraphy-measured effects: pooled night-sleep treatments increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes/night on average (driven by +38 minutes time in bed) but did not improve sleep efficiency; nap treatment increased daytime sleep by ~14 minutes/day and occurred in a higher-quality office environment

Pooled night-sleep increases produced no detectable improvements in overall index, work, well-being, cognition, or preferences; they reduced labor supply by about 9 minutes/day and slightly lowered earnings

The nap treatment significantly improved an overall summary index (0.12 SD), with positive effects on productivity, psychological well-being, lab cognition (attention), and savings/present-bias measures, but reduced work time during nap period

Sleep measurement used wrist actigraphy worn continuously; actigraphy is a validated field method correlating highly with polysomnography for sleep-wake detection and provides measures of time in bed, sleep duration, and sleep efficiency

Expert priors (surveyed sleep scientists and economists) predicted sizable economic benefits of +0.5 hour night sleep (median predicted ~7% increase in output), predictions strongly contradicted by trial results

Possible explanations: (a) lab studies induce extreme acute deprivation that may not generalize to modest field increases, (b) low sleep quality/efficiency in this setting may blunt marginal benefits of additional night sleep, and (c) timing matters so naps and nighttime sleep are not perfect substitutes

Instrumental-variable analysis and per-minute estimates indicate per-minute effects of nap sleep are significantly more positive than per-minute effects of nighttime sleep for overall index, cognition, preferences, and psychological well-being, though naps crowd out more labor per minute

Conclusions: in this urban poor Chennai context, people can increase nighttime sleep via more time in bed but gains yield little short-term economic returns; office naps yield short-term cognitive, well-being, and some economic gains but have opportunity costs

Policy implication and recommendation: field measurement of sleep and context-specific interventions are critical; interventions that improve sleep efficiency or provide workplace naps merit further study before generalizing lab evidence across contexts

Limitations acknowledged: short treatment horizon (three weeks), single-city/sample external validity concerns, inability to isolate timing versus quality mechanisms for nap vs night differences, and limited power for some heterogeneity tests
